Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2014 06:30PM MusicLover wrote: Acetaminophen (Tylenol) is not a blood thinner but Ibuprohen (Advil) and Aspirin are so that may be why onc. says no to the latter two (definitely can't take those when you are on another blood thinner like Coumadin or Lovenox).  I wanted to mention that I had flu like symptoms with Zometa after the first injection and not since then and yes, it is a side effect.  Also, if you have a bone met on your rib cage it will tend to bother you more in the beginning of your treatments because of the healing effects (I believe).  That's what happened to me, I felt a little burning sensation where my bone mets are for at least the first 3 months or so.  Also, I know everyone has their own pain thresholds but I think you will begin to tolerate more pain over time. Best regards.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2014 01:41AM MusicLover wrote: How about this? This morning I saw a local commercial about a car show that has been happening every September for the past few years.  At the car show, they do prostate cancer screening by checking men's PSA levels.  If the levels are abnormal the men (should) follow up with additional testing on their own.  Their idea is that men won't go for the testing on their own so they attract them with something they enjoy and there you go. I started wondering how can breast cancer awareness implement something similar. I know there are mammography vans that go to different locations, etc.  But I came up with a somewhat crazy idea, what if they only let women walk at these fundraisers for bc if the women show proof that they went for a mammogram. I realize that mammo's aren't perfect and all of that but I thought that if this was required for women in a specified age group (of course, those that haven't already had a mastectomy) it would force people to take the walks more seriously. The walks themselves would symbolize a truly positive step in helping women fight breast cancer.  Crazy, right?  I think the organizers would just feel that less people would show up for the walks but I had to put this thought on paper (sorry, ladies).....

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2015 12:19PM MusicLover wrote: You'll be ok. What do they plan to do, mohs surgery? It is a surgery which insures that the least amount of your skin is removed but all of the cancer is removed, sort of like taking a breast tumor out and checking for clear margins.  There is also a crèam that they prescribe sometimes called aldara, it is used for genital worts but it kills off precancerous skin cancer.  I used a cream called curaderm to kill of the squamous naturally but I had a tiny spot and it took a long time to do it. Since it's on your back I would ask your dr. about mohs and then once it heals over you can ask your dr about following up with aldara.  Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2015 02:34PM MusicLover wrote: My squamous also was small flakey dry areas, I went to the dermatologist about something else and happened to mention it to her because it kept peeling and peeling and never healing and there you go, skin cancer. The punch biopsy took most of it off it seems but the dermatologist wanted to follow up with the aldara. Then when I had even smaller spots later on and the beginning of a spot of basal I used to curaderm and like I said it took awhile but I knew that it worked because when I applied it the spots would get all red and irritated and then finally it stopped doing that, so I knew it was gone. That's the same thing that happens with aldara.  My issue was that since they were on my face I did not want to get all cut up.  Again, best wishes.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2014 04:52PM MusicLover wrote: Here is a link to a video that I found awhile ago, it is a video of the pres. from MSKCC talking about what increases the possibility of us developing cancer https://search.yahoo.com/search;_ylt=Av56ViXwfO16MZKNTC1wTS.bvZx4?fr=yfp-t-901-s&toggle=1&cop=mss&ei=UTF-8&p=youtube%20memorial%20sloan%20kettering%20ceo%20sugar%20 I wish that I knew this stuff years ago, I think I would have added years on to my life and saved my self all of those horrible trips to the oncologist and all of the stress that is involved with a cancer diagnosis.  I really don't want to simplify things so much but I think if the establishment told people in an ad. campaign or something that sugar and carbs and protein increase your risk of cancer there would in fact be less cancer in the world.  You may find part of this video boring because you know a lot of what he says but it is kind of interesting that he states that we have been told to eat a diet which will decrease our risk of heart disease but if cancer runs in your family your diet should be a little different.  (He also talks about obesity having a link to cancer, I would not have fallen into that category but I definitely had a sweet tooth!) Maybe it wouldn't have made a difference but it is odd how there are so many things on the web that say that if you are fighting cancer you need to eliminate your sugar intake and carbs which we know turn into sugar.  I just think that Janice along with the radical remission folks have figured this out also.  Just a thought. I think our oncologists don't tell us this because we have cancer already but I do think there is a possibility that it can make a huge difference if we change our diets! I was skeptical about the fact that vegans and vegetarians get cancer too idea but I wonder how much sugar and carbs. they were eating.

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2014 07:04PM MusicLover wrote: If you read about the author's reason for writing this book, she basically says that so much work has been done creating statistics on those who succumb to cancer that she wanted to write about those who overcame a terminal diagnosis.  I think it is interesting but there are absolutely no guarantees.  I think what she means by following your intuition is that you do your research and pick your plan of action that way.  As for the supplements/herbs, that is part of your plan of action.  The plan of action is different for everyone.  From everything that I have researched, the people that have healed themselves naturally really believe that what they are doing is going to work for them.  The people that I am speaking of weren't necessarily terminal.  Just to clarify, the author researched all of these people (I think 1,000 people over 10 years) and those are the top nine factors.  She did not list anything obscure and some of the people definitely did obscure things like go to a healer, ie. John of God.  I have not read the book yet but I do wonder if she had a timeframe for the people she researched.  I do hope that they have been "cancer free" for a good period of time (hopefully, 10+ years). I have a friend who is a stage IV lung cancer survivor, after speaking to him and learning about my dx I quickly realized (maybe I'm wrong) that when we are diagnosed if our situation is considered life threatening or if we have an oncologist who wants to take a curative approach, they will treat us aggressively (like my lung cancer survivor friend).  Some times it works out well and people are "cured" through conventional medicine going this route (again, no guarantees).  What is interesting about our disease in comparison to many other cancers, is that once we are labeled stage IV they will continue to treat us even if they might have "cured" us (I guess because all of these different meds that are available, unlike say for lung cancer.)  My friend has amazed his oncologist but at the same time the oncologist has told him that it will eventually come back and it will kill him at some point.  I have only found 2 stories of women who were diagnosed with stage IV breast cancer and they are not being treated with anything now and they have stated that they are "cancer free".  Maybe 3 stories, because it sounds like Dr. Oz may have interviewed someone in this category (I found that out by doing a search on the web but he never clearly states that she was stage IV just that her dr's gave her 5 years).  I definitely do not think that he is advocating opting for alternative over conventional medicine.  I think he is just talking about the situations in which conventional medicine does not offer a "cure" and what has worked for some people.  Another story is of a woman named Joyce O'Brien.  I read most of her book, "Choose to Live" and I immediately found a discrepancy.  She mentions that when she was dx stage IV they didn't offer her radiation or chemo but later in the book she states that she is so glad that she did not opt for the chemo and that she looked for alternate therapy, hmmm???  We all have heard about healing miracles.  Ebru may have a good point.

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2014 07:29PM MusicLover wrote: The author considers radical remission to be • a person’s cancer goes away without using any conventional medicine; or  • a cancer patient tries conventional medicine, but the cancer does not go into remission, so he or she switches to alternative methods of healing, which do lead to a remission; or • a cancer patient uses conventional medicine and alternative healing methods at the same time in order to outlive a statistically dire prognosis (i.e., any cancer with a less than 25 percent chance of five-year survival). Here are the nine overlapping factors the author's research uncovered.  1. Radically changing your diet. 2. Taking control of your health. 3. Following your intuition. 4. Using herbs and supplements. 5. Releasing suppressed emotions. 6. Increasing positive emotions. 7. Embracing social support. 8. Deepening your spiritual connection. 9. Having strong reasons for living.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2014 12:33PM MusicLover wrote: I haven't been here long but don't get hung up on being NED, my onc told me that and from what I have seen I agree with him now.  I think what is more important is that your treatment is either keeping you stable or that you are showing regression and that you feel ok and it seems like you have all of that working for you right now.  I, like you and everyone else in our situation wants to know how long or better yet that we can be around for a long time but as EnglishMajor said there is no way for them to tell.  Not only does the medication need to be working, we also have to be up for the fight and ready to deal with some pain and whatever else this disease brings to us.  I know of a lady who had similar bone mets to you and lived for 15yrs after her stage IV diagnosis, in addition, when her onc wanted to put her on chemo she refused and found a new onc so she could stay on AI's for the whole 15yrs!  I think she passed on due to health problems created from the pain killers she was on and she just didn't want to fight any longer.  (I also try and stay hopeful that some amazing medication will be available in the near future, call me delusional but whatever helps.) Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2014 11:09AM - edited Mar 9, 2014 11:56AM by MusicLover PieMistress, Follow your suspicions, breast pain is a sign of breast cancer.  I hope that you are wrong but it is best to pursue it and have peace of mind.  You need a mammo, ultrasound and biopsy if they do determine there is something to biopsy.  If all of that turns up nothing, I would ask for an MRI or PET/CT scan (even if you have to pay out of pocket for it, get it done).   Since your lymph node was clean that's good but it's almost a year ago.  Sometimes with breast cancer there is no primary tumor that's why I am suggesting the MRI or PET/CT scan.  Best of luck!

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2014 07:58AM - edited Feb 20, 2014 08:10AM by MusicLover  I am sad for all of us. Thermography is another one of those things that the holistic people push because it is less detrimental to us, no radiation involved. If your friend got scans they may have gotten her a little more time but you never know what would have happened. I really think some people are lucky for one reason or another when they claim diet saved them and there are bunch of them on youtube/the web.  But unless a biopsy was performed you just never know.  If they claim something lit up on a PET scan and that's the only definitive proof that the cancer spread well, we all know that's not reliable. I have reached out to so many people pushing a special diet to cure cancer and a lot of testimonials are for using it as an adjuvant therapy, not as a cure. Many want a fee for coaching/advice (radar up on that one) but several people have given me a lot of information for free through email and they have even spoken to me on the phone.  I do believe that watching our sugar intake should help us, I hope. Other than that, any diet changes helping us would be a miracle. Let's consider Ruth Heidrich, she is very nice and she is doing very well.  She had a double mastectomy, her cancer spread to bones & lungs as per a PET scan but I don't know if anything was biopsied and then she worked with Dr. McDougall with a diet as opposed to chemo/rads and this got her cancer free. But if this worked so well, Dr. McDougall would have several testimonials of cases but she is the only one for breast cancer that I am aware of. Dr. Lodi seems like he believes in what he is doing and he is a very good speaker but he will even say that the only thing that we our guaranteed is "today". This is another sad thing that I thought of, the National Cancer Institute states the estimated new cases and deaths from breast cancer in the United States in 2013:  That's @17-18%, but I can't help but wonder how many of these cases were DCIS because it is up for debate as to whether or not this is really cancer, don't get me wrong some times DCIS cases prove fatal too.  It would be more interesting to see how many DCIS, IDC & ILC cases resulted in death. I do realize that the deaths aren't from the new cases from the same year (that would be awful) but I wonder how bad the statistics really look, how many of us with invasive cancer die from our cancer?  I think it might be more like 50%, that's my guess and if my guess is good, that's a very bad statistic. (Just think of the # of women that you personally knew to have had breast cancer and the number of women who have died from it. I know of 6 deaths and 9 surviving cases so that's @40% still not a great statistic).  Something to think about... PS - I know that there a lot of women who prefer the alternative treatment but if I wasn't stage IV I wouldn't even consider thinking about these alternative methods.  What I say now after my experience is this, "Cancer is a gunfight, don't show up with a sword".  Look at Amy Robach, I don't know what kind of breast cancer she has but she is getting chemo. I wonder if she is using the cold cap because she still has a lot of hair.  I do hope that she comes forth with the details. I know it is very personal but I think it can be very helpful.  Suzanne Somers' may have had a DCIS? This is the information that can be helpful to women making these life and death decisions. (Alternative vs. Conventional).

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2014 07:43AM MusicLover wrote: I have been eating a little vegetable soup too because it seems to fill me up a bit better.  I wish I could start all over again and watch what I ate/drank just to see if it would have made a difference.  I have always been thin and always had a huge appetite. I was thinking it was enough that I cut out sugar and starches and a whole bunch of other things. (I want the pre-breast cancer me back, I know we all feel that way).  Adey, Do you have any tips on food to eat to feel full?  I have been eating fruit (berries) for breakfast and a salad for lunch and dinner with a cup of soup sometimes.  The salads consist of various lettuce and veggies and almonds and sunflower seeds. I munch on nuts and fruit for snacks now in between meals because I am still hungry. My problem was that I was always thin, I could eat anything and remain thin. So I ate whatever I liked, I had 3 meals a day and rarely ate in between, maybe some ice cream at night or chocolate (I do still eat the chocolate it's just 85% dark and up). I'm 5'6" and weighed 130, now I'm 115 or less somedays.  Thanks for the advice everyone!

This disease truly does S U C K !  Sorry for the language... but I hope you are doing ok on tx.  I have seen you post before, you have always been so sweet.  Thanks for your input.  I have a friend who was testing everyone's ph level at his house a few years ago and he tested mine & said I was too acidic, I just thought, sure, right. Now I am doing all of this reading on cancer and sure enough there is a lot of information out there that states cancer lives in an acidic environment.  The raw vegan diet is supposed to help a person become and stay alkaline, I wish I took more interest in the past.  It may not have made a difference but I would have piece of mind that I did my best to prevent this crappy disease.  Anyhow, it is much more difficult to back track with cancer but I am trying to give it a shot and hope for the best.
Posts.Title: Raw Food Diet? MusicLover MusicLover

Posts.Content: MusicLover wrote: Hello BCO Stage IV Sisters, I have been reading a lot of interesting information about a raw food vegan diet.  Yes, I am still on this kick to cure myself (praying).  I was wondering if any of you have tried this and have noticed any benefits?  I realize that we really can't be certain if it is the diet or the medication but I just wanted to throw this out to all of you to see if anyone else has gone as crazy as me, just kidding.  (I do believe that there must be something to this...)  Although, I did read something on the web specifically stating that women diagnosed with breast cancer should not think they cure themselves with this diet because the breast cancer may have been caused by radiation, or stuff in the environment but I was thinking maybe my breast cancer was caused by the hormones in the meat I ate, or the fact that I over cooked everything and stripped the nutrients out of my food therefore, I was not getting any nutrients.  I realize that there are vegans on this board who still got breast cancer but I feel that it can't hurt me and hopefully, I can keep this diet up. Thank you and I hope you are able to enjoy your day! As per PET scan, 3 or 4 nodules in the right breast, 2 of which were actually in the middle of my chest, the other 2 were side by side in the breast. Also DCIS in the left breast. Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2014 01:42PM MusicLover wrote: No, they should not be able to tell just from looking at your scan. You need them to do a bone biopsy on one of the mets, two problems first is, is it possible to reach the spot to do the biopsy and second problem, is if you do have more then one spot lighting up and the first one that they biopsy comes up negative, they should biopsy the next spot and so on, so on.  One way or another I hope that you can have stage IV confirmed before you begin treatment for it. You can't be truly certain about only one lymph node unless they remove them and dissect(?) them, none of my lymph nodes lit up on the PET scan but one was biopsied positive for cancer. (When you say no TM's the level is 0?). I hope this helps you.   Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2013 03:38PM - edited Nov 10, 2013 03:58PM by MusicLover Hi AmyQ, Is that your beautiful baby? Adorable. One thing I learned very quickly is if I don't ask the "right" questions to my Onc I just get another rosey picture painted. I don't think I am wrong about this but I believe that the biophosphonate is really to help strengthen your bones because the Femara (& in my case, Zoladex) have weakening effects on bones (post menopausal stuff). I have read that the biophosphonates may help with the healing of the bone mets but I have also heard that may not be the case either. They probably have no way of knowing which is doing which, if it is the AI that's healing them alone or the biophosphonate is helping. I hope your pharmacist is incorrect for both of our sakes. I want to ask my Onc about radiation therapy if the bone mets are getting worse, based on what I have read on this board that seems to be a real good way of getting the cancer out of there. But I imagine that it can only be used on certain spots. If anyone with more experience with radiation on bone mets could comment that would be great, for instance, what was the deciding factor to use radiation therapy? and what are the down sides (how much damage to surrounding tissues, etc.) Thanks for the help.

But what I read from all of the posts on this thread is such optimism.  My hope is that there is a cure in my lifetime (our lifetimes) too, so we can have our peace back.  But Brandall may be correct and that is ok too.  I know that I would have peace if it was announced that we could be treated chronically for an infinite amount of time.  To answer your questions, oh boy!  This is something that I complained about to my onc when I was dx, very hesitantly, I might add, because I quickly read all of the stories on BCO which confused the heck out of me.  Some stage IV's went aggressive in the beginning and had great success, others did not have the same success.  Oddly enough, I found someone who was only given Tamoxifen and has been NED for 7 years, she eats "vegan like".  I searched for complimentary ideas that I could implement to help me, such as various diet changes and crazy cancer cures which I don't have true faith in.  It has all been very exhausting.  I obviously settled on the path my onc chose for me with the AI's and I have looked for hope that I found in other women's stories.   I have eliminated meat except for occasional fish, eliminated almost all sugar and dairy, is it helping?  I have no idea. (If and when I am convinced it is helping I will let everyone know.)

Posts.Content: May 6, 2014 02:05PM MusicLover wrote: First, I read some of your blog to find out what you're dealing with physically as a result of the cancer.  You have definitely been through a lot over the past 2 years. When I first started treatment I had a lot of pain in the places where the cancer is but it did get better, so I hope that is the case for you too. I am having a lot of difficulty with the mental piece of this too.  I am hoping now that the weather is getting better and since I enjoy gardening it will take my mind off the cancer.  I see that you like gardening too.  Try and not think too far out into the future and do things that you like to do, of course, things that don't cause you any pain.  I only think about the treatment working and for a long time. I know the whole "positive thinking" thing bugs a lot of people but it does help me and it may help you too. I hate the treatment and I hate the scans too, I sense that is what you are saying on your blog also.  But for whatever reason I ended up with this horrible disease and all of the medical stuff is keeping me around and I know you feel that way too.  There are some really wonderful drugs on the horizon which may even cure us, honestly (anti-CD47).  I think about that and it keeps me going (and I don't care if others think I'm delusional). I also changed my diet to help me feel empowered.  I hope that I helped... Oh, and in my opinion it hasn't helped me to get suggestions from the healthy people in my life - that just may be me though.  They mean well but some times I get one of the comments from the thread "Stupid things people say to MBC patients" and I don't want to hear that stuff.

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2016 09:04PM - edited Jan 26, 2016 09:06PM by MusicLover Hmmm, I don't think anyone here thinks of our requests for funding in those terms. I think we MBC patients/BC patients and their loved ones have asked for more research funding it is to make certain that when people donate to a breast cancer organization we would like to see a big chunk of that money put towards research. I think that when money is collected for lung cancer I would hope that it would be the same. Now, when money is donated to the American Cancer Society that is a different story and I don't think anyone on BCO has ever asked for more of that money to go to bc research over another cancer's research. With that said, some of the latest things that I have read is that some researchers are looking at cancer as one disease or something along those lines. Time will tell if that idea will work but there are many drugs which are being used for multiple types of cancer. As for her statement, " I have heard that some metastatic breast cancer patients have told patients with other cancers that metastatic breast cancer needs and/or deserves more funding than they do". I don't believe that this is true.

I hope you find answers soon.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2014 05:48PM - edited Sep 7, 2014 12:54PM by MusicLover I haven't been here long enough to say. I just added myself to the thread "What age were you at diagnosis?" or something like that.  I have thought about this a lot and I want your opinions.  First off, I have a newbie question.  If you are treated in the earlier stages I read that there is a test that your onc can do on your cancer cells to see how effective a particular chemo tx will be, is that the case and how often do you think that it is used? I know of the onco test, but that is to see if you need chemo or don't, correct?  Ok,  now here goes for the crazy....that thread about the age at dx, got me thinking because some women state the orig stage and then they give age at stage IV.  I think it would be interesting to see info for orig dx like age, stage size of tumor (largest if more then one), first line tx and then age at stage IV.  To me it should be enough to see that 40K women die of this disease in the US alone (I think it is 500k annually internationally?) but to see that women who were dx orig at an early stage, or late stage with a relatively small tumor or no tumor at all.  It just boggles my mind and should tear on the heart stings of humanity that something needs to be done.  I feel this way about cancer in general but do other cancers recur the way that breast cancer seems to? I am becoming better educated on this everyday - is it helping? Not sure... (every time I read an old post of mine, I find some error...)

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2014 01:05PM MusicLover wrote: I think we should all be PhD's after our dx and the research we put into it.  Thank you all, if anything it gets the mental juices flowing. Mzmerz, I have read about Dr. B. too, was he mentioned in Kelley's book too? I think there must be some value to reducing the sugar that we intake but I think everyone will make their own mind on how they want to live.  Most people on the web calling themselves a cancer coach suggest to reduce the sugar intake. Kris Carr is another person like that, she has a pretty informative website if anyone is interested. Anko66, It's funny that you mention the role of the mind since the first thing I did today was watch a youtube video from a guy who basically is preaching "The Secret" and he even talked about the women on that film who cured her breast cancer by thinking all good thoughts.  Then I watched part of a video from Bruce Lipton on the same subject but he started saying that we assume our parents' diseases by thinking that we will get them.  For me it was just the opposite, my Mom never had cancer so assumed I would be lucky like her and I assumed I wouldn't get breast cancer so I went straight to stage IV (lucky me!).  The only thing that makes a little sense to me, is when they talk about how if you say you don't want something you will get it but honestly, what woman hasn't said that to themselves when someone mentions breast cancer.  I just hate how everything comes back to the possible mistakes that I made, I hate the wrong foods or had the wrong thoughts. Here is a question: Does God give us the diseases we get? or Is it our actions that cause them? Or is it just an imperfection in our bodies? What else would explain it when children get cancer? Isn't it just a biological imperfection?  Some people are exposed to so much stuff and they don't get cancer while others do.  So I do wonder how much difference my diet is going to play in my longevity? Last but not least, I said to one of my girlfriends that I would much rather have a quick death and she said that she has read a lot and the suffering is supposed to bring us closer to God.  Does that make us feel any better? I would say no.
Posts.Title: Curing the Incurable by Dr. William Donald Kelley MusicLover exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2014 04:14PM MusicLover wrote: Caryn, I agree, I don't think we caused this disease by something we thought or didn't think, that was my point.  I don't want the burden of that idea, I was trying to demonstrate how I don't agree with that thinking at all.  I have listened to the studies of how the women in China are not getting this disease as often as they do once they come here & start living our lifestyle so that makes me wonder if it was something that I ate or how I lived.  But I would prefer to think that it is just an imperfection in our bodies that is not in our control, I think that is a better explanation considering that people are born with abnormalities all of the time.  I would rather be released of the burden that I could have done something differently to prevent this disease. That is what I meant by questioning if what I eat now will really have an effect on how long I stick around. The only regret I have is giving up the control that I had in preventing my death from this disease by believing my physician's dx and not doing any further investigating but I am not sure that things would have turned out much different had I taken another path, that I will never know.  My last comment on God, is not to say that any of us are guaranteed a perfect life, of course not, we all know that someday we are going to die and we don't have any control over when and how that will happen.  I never thought I wouldn't live a similar life to the life that my mom has lived as far as longevity goes but that's probably how we all think. Some people who are very religious welcome the thought of going to heaven, I would much rather have had several more healthy and happy years with my family before I was confronted with my mortality (not unlike most of us thrown into this situation).  I totally understand your point of view.  Caryn, You are doing very well physically and you don't seem to be very fearful of the dx.  The toughest thing that I am going through right now, is the fear. So I was/am trying to do whatever I can to feel like I have some control.  I feel fairly well and I can function normally too but the fear of knowing that I am in this situation is still difficult mainly when I am waking up in the morning.  I have a very peaceful sleep but then once I realize that my reality is back I have a minor panic attack, not enough for me to take a Xanax but I just wish I could get that to go away.  I also was a very healthy person so the thought of the monthly tx's and the quarterly scans make me a little crazy too. Do you experience this at times? You seem very calm about everything all of the time, is that the case?  Or can you offer some advice for dealing with it? (Not including a psychologist or meds). Thank you, your opinion is always welcomed or I wouldn't post these ideas.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2014 09:45AM MusicLover wrote: Bestbird, I love your analogy.  I know many of us have a wonderful quality of life and that's great but for me I almost need someone to hold my hand when I go out now.  So your analogy is great, because if I was blind, barefoot and dropped in a mine field I would definitely want someone to hold my hand.  LizLemon, I agree with you also that I don't like when people refer to it as a chronic illness either and then compare it to diabetes.  I don't know that much about diabetes but I think diabetics can stay on the same medication forever, correct?  If that was the case for us then I would be ok with calling it a chronic illness.  I think that is the goal but conventional medicine is not there yet.  I am thankful that there are a lot of medications available for us but nothing is guaranteed to work for any length of time. (I still look like a wounded deer in headlights when I go in for my treatment.  The nurses are very nice. They'll try and make me feel better so they'll compare MBC to a chronic illness like diabetes. I just want to scream out, " A few months ago I was a non-cancer patient just like you" - luckily, I don't do that because I don't know what they are going through.)
Posts.Title: MBC is Not a "Journey" Bestbird cliff

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2014 07:19AM MusicLover wrote: Right now, I think my obituary is going to read more like this: "At first she carried on normally but as the months went by it began to sink in that she had the disease that she dreaded. She was ok with the daily medication since it wasn't harsh at first, but she dreaded the treatments that were necessary every 4 weeks and the quarterly scans because up until she was diagnosed with cancer she was hardly sick a day in her life.  Honestly, she was the picture of health. She felt betrayed by her body and soon, she felt defeated by this disease so she began crawling up into a little ball on her "spot" on the couch in the den. There wasn't a day that went by that she didn't cry.   She spent many hours looking feverishly for a cure and after eating a mainly raw vegan diet and drinking her share of wheatgrass juice she succumbed to this horrible disease."  I am actually very grateful for all the wonderful things in my life but (and you knew that there would be a but) I would have loved several more cancer free years then what I have been given.  My heart truly goes out to anyone who has had to deal with cancer or any disease at young age. I actually hope that I become as strong as all of you and that my obituary can read more like the one that EnglishMajor posted.  My glass is half empty now...it was always half full before but I never faced this big of a challenge before.  I am going to look for my 85% dark chocolate right now (I have managed to keep it on my diet).

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2014 04:41PM MusicLover wrote: Prayers go out to you Katie. xoxoxo My onc said ok to Turmeric (I started taking the capsules about a month before my dx) but he said no to Artemisinin, although he didn't know anything about it.  My DH discovered it and someone on this board wrote about it awhile ago.  Artemisinin is supposed to work like a chemo but only go after the cancer cells.  If it was a miracle cure we would all know about it but it must have some good effects for going after the cancer cells. Recently, my husband said that it might make the chemos less effective or something to that effect.  I would be cautious about using it but you may want to research it and see what you think.

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2014 05:48PM - edited Apr 5, 2014 05:53PM by MusicLover Dr. Linda Vahdat or Dr. Ann Moore at Weill Cornell in NYC.  I know that Linda stays up on her game and I heard great things about Ann. (first names is just easier) Ann did not take my insurance but Linda did, she was my oncologist on diagnosis but I wanted convenience so I moved closer to where I live. I use Dr. Steven Sugarman at Memorial Sloan Kettering in Commack if you want to stay on Long Island.  I also heard that Julie Fasano is very good there but I have never met her. I recently met with a Dr. Stephen Malamud at Beth Israel in NYC, I think he is amazing (I only met with him once though).  He recently ran a webinar on metastatic breast cancer, so I think he stays on top of everything for sure.  He seems bright and is very, very caring! If I ever feel the need to change I would go to him, it's just a bit inconvenient.  I hope this helps. I am just adding on that I have extremely high anxiety too and based on that if it is not too inconvenient for you, I really suggest Dr. Malamud 1st, then Dr. Moore or Dr. Fasano.  Verify that they accept your insurance, that may help with your decision making.

Posts.Content: MusicLover wrote: I am just wondering if this happened to anyone else at any stage and what the outcome was at the particular stage that you were diagnosed.  I feel like this was a death sentence for me from the beginning.  Honestly, how does a surgeon get clean margins on a tumor that is laying on your sternum? I am not talking about bone mets, I mean a tumor. It was small but they literally turned the mammography machine sideways (vertical) stuck whatever they could into it.  I also had an ill-defined tumor that looked snake like next to my sternum also. (The lady who did by ultrasound asked me if this crap was a scar, so I am assuming this doesn't happen that often). I honestly shook every night I went to bed last fall because I never thought that what I had was breast cancer and I walked around like this for a couple of months.  I thought this only happened after being treated for breast cancer when the cancer may return in an unusual spot.  It just has bothered me so much for a year now that I just don't know how they could have gotten me in remission.  I know this is cancer and it is unpredictable but really, has anyone else experienced such a thing before a stage IV diagnosis and they put you into remission?  (I do get a good night's sleep now thankfully but during the hours I am awake I can't help but think I have been cursed or something). Thanks for reading about my nightmare or daymare or whatever the heck it is.) As per PET scan, 3 or 4 nodules in the right breast, 2 of which were actually in the middle of my chest, the other 2 were side by side in the breast. Also DCIS in the left breast. Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2014 08:57PM MusicLover wrote: I was starting to research the blue zones a little bit too.  I sometimes wish I took more concern about my health in the past but hindsight is 20-20.  I did like living that carefree life that I was living.  I never thought it would bite me in the butt like the way that it has. I exercised and I didn't live on donuts and soda but I could have eaten more healthy foods. (It's  like smoking, some people can do it and it never seems to effect their health.) I don't know if you noticed what I posted on another thread that I noticed that there seems to be a lot of us on this board who come from English/Irish heritage. Sure enough, if you watch that youtube video that Mrs Chang posted, the presenter puts up a map of the world and shows the cases of breast cancer by % in different colors in all parts of the world.  The areas that have the highest percentage were all colonized by the British more or less.  India and Hong Kong were the only locations that didn't fall into the high percentage category but I wonder how many Brits relocated there permanently.  It's just interesting to me, may there is something to my idea.  Maybe it is the heritage along with the diet.  I have watched a lot of Paul Nison's youtube videos and today I found another web site Arnold's Way (then I realized that these guys know each other).  Arnold claims to have helped women cure their breast cancer with a raw food diet.  He is pretty specific about what I need to do. He has a video on youtube called 7 steps to staying young (I need 7 step to staying alive) but if anything, he is entertaining! How the hell did I get myself into this mess? It's 1 in 8 women now that will get bc.  Well, I have a group of 8 friends, woohoo lucky me!  If only my luck with the lottery was that good.  This is always going to stink and I knew that, we all knew that.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2014 11:50AM MusicLover wrote: Romansma, When you spoke to the 15yr survivor, did you ask how she is doing it?  I think the common thing amongst the long term survivors is that they do just live their lives. They take whatever medication that they need to deal with this crappy disease, I mean pain meds, anti-depressants and anxiety meds, whatever.  They just feel that their onc. will put them on something else when the current med. has failed. I am still in the phase of wishing this never happened, mad at myself for not being more pro-active and missing the me of the past (active, fun loving, not having to think about meds & scan results, etc.)  I also watch everyone else going on with their lives as normal but I know of woman who recently passed on from the chemotherapy they gave her, so out of respect for her I try to be thankful for each day. I made a friend who after 28yrs had a recurrence at 70 and she is going on 77 now and she just keeps going.  She has bad days too of course but she just feels that she will be around for a long time still and that's the bottom line. (One day at a time). Let's all do something that we really enjoy doing today (it may not be the most physical activity) but let's not think about the cancer while we are doing it.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 02:06PM MusicLover wrote: That's what I thought also.  I said something to that effect on my "Raw Food Diet?" thread.  I reread something this morning about her online because I couldn't remember her story that well, but she states that she had cancer 5 times (I think) and the last time the chemo was not shrinking her tumors but then she dropped dairy and the tumors started to shrink (????). You think like me because there a lot of stories on the web about diet changes healing cancer as opposed to the diet being the only treatment involved.  A lot of people eat a very healthy diet to recover from their conventional cancer treatment, that's fine but they are not always forthcoming with all of the information. You can't always figure it all out until you look into their story.   I also found a youtube video of the CEO from Sloan Kettering discussing how sugar can be contributed to causing cancer. Bottom line is we will probably never know why we got this wretched cancer and we will never know if any of these crazy diets will help us.  So, try the diet changes if you like but beware about what you read on the internet. (There's a very nice lady who used a raw food diet to help her after her melanoma had spread.  I asked her through emails about Linda McCartney getting breast cancer and the fact that she was a vegetarian for many years and she had a good answer for me, she said that we don't know how much of her diet was raw and how much sugar she ate. At least, she was ready for my question.).
Posts.Title: Curing the Incurable by Dr. William Donald Kelley MusicLover exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 11:48PM MusicLover wrote: Yes, exactly.  That's exactly what I mean.  I have spent months on this, sadly.  Surgery is treatment and sometimes if caught early enough or maybe even not early enough but if the cancer isn't the "traveling" kind, surgery is enough.  There are many on the web who claim to have "cured" their cancer but in actuality they are using holistic methods as adjuvant therapy after surgery but they are not very forthcoming about the situation.  In fact they are deceptive about the situation.  I know we are all smarter then this but sometimes when there isn't much hope we can be mislead.  (Yeah and unless a biopsy has been performed and analyzed by a pathologist, well we know that a lump in the breast may not always be cancer).  Caryn, You're a smart lady and so am I.  I know I am wasting my time looking for the silver bullet.  I'm just about done with it. I have so many other things I should be spending my time on. Sadly if I keep this up, my kids are going to remember me as a crazy person, crying often and looking for a non-existent silver bullet instead of spending more quality time with them.  I really do hope that I am done with it already.

They are located in Westchester, NY and service a 50 mile radius. They can also accommodate clients in the state of Vermont. If you are out of their service area they can offer an online option that can be done from anywhere in the world. For more information: Phone:  914-725-1836  Email: info@thrumyeyes.org  Their website is: http://www.thrumyeyes.org/ The woman who founded this organization is a breast cancer survivor.  The organization was featured on WNBC news in NY metro area this morning and it looked very good. Posts.Content: May 22, 2015 02:08PM - edited May 22, 2015 02:21PM by MusicLover I am curious to see the results that Heidi will be posting since I went through the same process that you are going through right now HLB.  I asked MO about this and brought in reports from various clinical trials and his bottom line answer was I can do better than that when he saw their survival stats.  I had a different case then you because I never had surgery to my breast and I wasn't certain that I wanted surgery so I backed down (location of my cancer is weird - some in breast some in the middle of my chest - crazy unlucky crap I was dealt).  One of the requirements was to be treated with surgery and then radiation to bone mets.  I found a place in Florida that was doing this but the clinical trials that I found were conducted in Rochester, NY and also Japan (MO laughed at me for this one).  I am not certain that what I discovered was proton therapy but it sounds similar, maybe it was SBRT to bone mets (I am no expert so I apologize if this sounds incorrect).  This is one of those scenarios were you don't want to be regretting not trying it, correct?  What would be the negative side of this? Can anyone tell you that? Like I said, I am very curious to see the results that they have obtained so far.  Is it possible for you to speak to a former patient who has had long term success with this?  How long have they been doing this treatment for?  I think the interesting thing is that I have a friend who had stage IV lung cancer and his tumor was inoperable and he had one bone met.  They gave him a chemo cocktail and radiated his bone met and he has been NED with no meds for 10+ years (maybe 15 - my memory is going) but for breast cancer they rarely try and "cure" us if we are stage IV.  I wish you the best and I hope that you are a trail blazer for others. (Why not have your MO speak to the dr. in Florida? He won't do that?  Take Leggo's advice - schmooze a little...I would politely say "this is my life, when I run out of options I don't want to have regrets that I didn't try this." Also ask him what the negative side would be.  Don't you get MRI's regularly anyway or some type of scan? If that is the case, I hope he would order the MRI for you. I wouldn't request something this big through an email, ask for a consult with him.)  http://www.aboutcancer.com/oligomets_milano_0108.htm http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3995374/ (maybe I showed him this too) I can't find the Japanese based one, only one for stage IV prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2014 07:29PM - edited Dec 16, 2014 07:43PM by MusicLover I am at MSKCC also I think they are trained to be that way, honestly, they stay positive, positive. My MO does not really like me asking questions, he answers them but he is a little defensive.  I had to ask for PET scans because they prefer CT scans over them, I think that the PET scan offers a little more detail (a very reputable MO at another hospital suggested that I request the PET scan).  I did read on BCO that there are advantages to all of these tests.  Even with the PET scan it depends on who reads it as to what the report states.  I just looked at the report for a CT scan that they did on me and the only detail offered for bone mets is stable or new, no sizes or SUV's. What exactly does it say in the report about the bone met (the one that either is clearing up very well or got worse)? Also, what do they mean by your mom's blood tests being the best they've been? Are they referring to the tumor markers?  My tumor markers seem to be consistent with my scans, in other words, if my tumor markers go up then my scans show increased cancer activity and possibly a new bone met. But most mo's do not rely on tumor markers, so I would  suggest that your mom requests a couple of consecutive PET scans, she will then know if things are getting better or worse, the SUV's will be stated for each bone met and if they SUV's are going down that is good, going up is not good.  Are you aware that your mom can access the results from all of her tests online?  This is a great aid to see trends and get a feel for what is happening with her cancer. (https://my.mskcc.org/login?logout=true) I hope this is helpful and I am interested to see what others say. Best wishes to you. (Lindsey, By the way, how are you doing?)

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2014 05:33PM MusicLover wrote: I live on Long Island and I should have been high alert for this disease but I was not.  Yes, Long Island had a lot of farmland but then you have a lot of fertilizing and we also had a huge Aerospace industry and some chemical cleanups were performed on former properties of such, so there you go.  We also have golf courses which do major fertilizing and we now have spraying of the mosquitos to prevent the spread of west nile virus.  Maybe some of us are more sensitive to these chemicals then others. Ok, here is one for you, I think my breast cancer started right after I had menstrated 2 weeks apart.  That almost never happened to me before. So something threw my hormones off and there you go.  I don't know?  It's the environment, it's what we eat, it's the chemicals, it's stress, it's our lifestyle,  it's the hormones that have been added to the food we ate over the years??? It is too late for us but it would be nice if someone figured it out. Yeah, I hear in Asia they call it the "Rich Woman's Disease" (in other words, wealthy people eat more lavishly?)  I would go with the fast food reason for me.  I also barbecued red meat often and the carcinogens there in aren't good for you. I just wish there was a cure!

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2014 09:06PM MusicLover wrote: I apologize for stating what I meant incorrectly, I definitely think that they would let you know if they were worried but they definitely do the rah-rah positive thing whenever possible (I think that is probably a lot better then being all down and such).  Have you tried looking at your mom's report online?  I do suggest that you do that, you can compare previous scan reports and get a full list of tumor marker values on one page.  It is very helpful, you can also send messages to her onc.  Come to think of it, if I were you I would read the report for the CT scan and if you think it is not clear then I would message the onc. and ask her to have the radiologist clarify or if you are truly confident about TM's view them online and if they are improving or basically staying the same then you may not want to question the scan.  I really do think that you would be happier with a PET scan, it will give you more details of what is happening.  You can request the PET scan and see what onc says.  When I did this, he actually said he had put in a request for one for me already and since then I have only be getting PET scans no more CT scans.  So glad to hear things are going well for your father.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2014 02:55PM MusicLover wrote: Annie & Pajim stated some other thoughts that I had but didn't add. I really have had 3 scans now all with different results. Let me explain the first one picked tiny nodules in my lungs, 3 in total the largest being 6mm.  Two oncs told me not to worry about those, too small to biopsy and they could be anything, they said. It also found two bone mets. That scan was the best equipment used on me so far.  Then I had CT scan 3 months into tx and it picked up only two bone mets but only one was the same as the original scan, I questioned my onc. & he said different equipment, different results but I think the radiologist reading it made a mistake.  Then another 3 months went by and I had a PET scan and this scan only picked up the original 2 bone mets.  This scan was with different equipment yet again.  A little crazy, correct?   Another point is that your onc. does not want to change your treatment if it is in fact working because whose to say the next treatment will work.  My onc. told me that he would never go back to a treatment that he has had me on already which means if he moves on to another treatment too soon then I will run out of options faster. That may be what your onc. is thinking too.  I know of lot women on here don't feel that tumor markers are a good indicator and their oncs say the same but if your onc. is unwilling to give you another scan in the near future, can you possibly use your tumor markers as an indicator of how things are going?  I do that in between scans, if the tumor markers are basically the same from month to month or possibly lower it helps give me better sense that I am doing ok.   Push for the same scan soon and let us know what happens,

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2015 06:03PM MusicLover wrote: Allyme, I have been wondering if any of your drs have told you that this is a chronic condition?  Most of us on here kinda laugh at that idea but being her2+ is a great thing I have read and is the closest to being treated chronic as we can get with this disease.  There is a lady on here that is ER-/PR-/HER2+ and is 12 years out from her stage IV diagnosis.  You need to find an oncologist who knows this stuff.  Another thing I was told to do is ask the oncs about their success stories with stage IV bc, in other words, ask them how many long term patients they have and if they have any 10+ year patients.  Everyone is different but this will help build your confidence in your onc.   You may want to start another thread called "Anyone know a good oncologist in the Pittsburgh area?", someone on here should be able to help you.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2014 01:20PM - edited Feb 3, 2014 01:26PM by MusicLover Sweetjam, I am making it my mission to help other women dx with bc because I don't want to see anyone else become a member of the stage IV club!  I have a girlfriend who was triple negative, she got 3 opinions from onc's & only one suggested that she do chemo. He basically told her if she was his wife that's what he would have her do!  That was over 10yrs ago and she has been living & loving life ever since!  (Ask your onc but I believe that chemo is the only adjuvant therapy available to a triple negative, I am not certain why they would suggest doing neo-adjuvant chemo if the tumor is in fact small, get a second opinion for that one because I think it would be better to do the chemo after the surgery to get the run away cells). Best of luck! Jpsara, Hang in there, I only wish I was in your shoes! I know many women with bmx's and most do not share the info with anyone that they do not have to, you may want to consider doing the same. It will give you time to adjust to your situation mentally and once you realize how much life you will be living you will be so glad that you are around to live it!  Praying for a cure.....no one should have to deal with this! The other ladies are correct though in stating that with neo-adjuvant chemo you will know if it is working or not, but definitely do the adjuvant chemo regardless!
